posts.title: A deadly E. coli outbreak hit 15 states, but the FDA chose not to publicize it | NBC News
top_comments:
I got sick with food poisoning (salmonella) and because my state has (or at least had) a robust health department, it was traced to a particular restaurant.

Whether or not the restaurant was negligent, or just had the bad luck of having some food that was spoiled, I have no idea. But the health department folks researched it  traced it. Amazing work. This is work that takes having adequate staffing. 

I don't know if this will happen anymore in my state. But I am very appreciative of the staff at the Dept of Health who helped me and told them as much that they were rock stars.
It literally never lists the 15 states in the entire article.
Beginning to sound a lot like Fahrenheit 451, isn't it?
Yes, America is failing its citizens to allow for corporate greed
“If we stop testing right now, we’d have very few cases, if any.”

Note this discovery is in conjunction with the US FDA cuts according to reuters [https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-fda-suspends-food-safety-quality-checks-after-staff-cuts-2025-04-17/](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-fda-suspends-food-safety-quality-checks-after-staff-cuts-2025-04-17/)

Highly concerning to US food safety, and wont make it easier for the US to export their agricultural products overseas.
Edit: this occured last year supposedly and was never reported, things are likely far worse now
TLDR: the states (cases per state) are AR (2), CO (1), IL (7), IN (8),KS (1), KY (1), MO (50), MT (1), ND (2), NE (3), OH (8), PA (1), SD (1), TN (1), WI (2)

posts.title: FSU shooting latest: 2 dead, 6 injured; 20-year-old suspect in custody
top_comments:
The son of a local sheriff's deputy allegedly opened fire near the Student Union at Florida State University in Tallahassee on Thursday, killing two people and injuring six others, authorities said.

The suspect -- 20-year-old Phoenix Ikner, a current FSU student -- was shot by responders and has been hospitalized, police said. He was taken into custody with non-life-threatening injuries, multiple law enforcement officials told ABC News.

Ikner is the son of a current Leon County sheriff's deputy, according to Sheriff Walter McNeil. He had access to one of his mother's personal weapons, which was one of the weapons found at the scene, the sheriff said. It appeared Ikner had a handgun and a shotgun with him, police said.

The suspect's mother has been a deputy with the department for more than 18 years and "her service to this community has been exceptional," McNeil said.

The suspect was also a "long-standing member" of the Leon County Sheriff's Office's Youth Advisory Council, McNeil said.

He was "engaged in a number of training programs that we have," the sheriff said, adding, "Not a surprise to us that he had access to weapons."...

>The suspect in the FSU shooting espoused white supremacist views and was removed from a political club, the group's president, Reid Seybold, said.

>Seybold said he was part of a club with the suspect at Tallahassee State College, where they both attended before transferring to FSU. He was president of a club called "political round table," where the suspect was asked not to return after repeated issues with the suspect's rhetoric.

>"Basically our only rule was no Nazis — colloquially speaking — and he espoused so much white supremacist rhetoric, and far-right rhetoric as well, to the point where we had to exercise that role," Seybold said.

posts.title: Boston immigration attorney, a citizen, told by DHS to leave the country in apparent mistake
'My home is worth millions but my kids can't afford to live here'
top_comments:
How about tax breaks on your first actual home

And massive taxes on any after that. 

And stop commodifying housing as it's taxing you on living

This is what it’s like in Miami. My parents bought their Redland ranch home on an acre for like 100k after Hurricane Andrew and now it’s worth almost a million dollars. I would love to raise a family where I grew up but it’s impossible unless you’re a doctor or a lawyer or a drug dealer.

Canada is an extreme example, but this is happening in a lot of places all over the world, and is concentrated in metropolitan areas. There are several factors, but the main ones are:

1. People think of their homes as investments and not houses to live in. This leads them to fight against literally any new housing, but particularly affordable housing because that will lower the value of their "investment." They also fight rezoning.

2. Businesses build portfolios of homes and apartment buildings to monetize.

3. People with the means buy multiple homes and rent the ones they aren't living in out, often times short term through Airbnb and Vrbo.

The ways to fix this are not easy, but if they don't happen it will just keep getting worse. Multifamily zoning laws need to be implemented. Permitting of new construction needs to be easier and much harder for residents to block. Tax incentives need to be granted for builders of less expensive, and more modest homes and multifamily buildings. Limits need to be placed on businesses and individuals who own multiple properties. Restrictions need to be placed on short term rentals (like only being able to rent them out for 3 months a year, and only if you live in the house for at least 7 months of that year).

Supply of affordable housing isn't going to happen naturally.

Would they be able to afford it if it was a $6-700K new construction?

Its intentional.
I'd like to point out that Vancouver is in Canada's Southwest.

Yeha way to go team. Then complain that your kids have to buy places hours away and you never see your grandkids.   
Such a stupid situation to be in…
Me growing up in Santa Cruz Cali. I could never live in my hometown now.
Same story in central NJ

we are apparently to stupid to solve 4 walls and a roof, i swear money and greed is going make this species go extinct because solving whatever existential crisis that's gonna pop up will be deemed to expensive, even tho money is not used as a actual resource in the making of anything

I think people are starting to realize that homeownership isn’t the investment it once was. It’s a liability. It’s only an investment if you get passive income from it. Otherwise it’s a money pit. You never really own your home. You’re just paying the government to live in it, as long as you keep it.

posts.title: 'My home is worth millions but my kids can't afford to live here'
top_comments:
How about tax breaks on your first actual home

And massive taxes on any after that. 

And stop commodifying housing as it's taxing you on living

This is what it’s like in Miami. My parents bought their Redland ranch home on an acre for like 100k after Hurricane Andrew and now it’s worth almost a million dollars. I would love to raise a family where I grew up but it’s impossible unless you’re a doctor or a lawyer or a drug dealer.

Canada is an extreme example, but this is happening in a lot of places all over the world, and is concentrated in metropolitan areas. There are several factors, but the main ones are:

1. People think of their homes as investments and not houses to live in. This leads them to fight against literally any new housing, but particularly affordable housing because that will lower the value of their "investment." They also fight rezoning.

2. Businesses build portfolios of homes and apartment buildings to monetize.

3. People with the means buy multiple homes and rent the ones they aren't living in out, often times short term through Airbnb and Vrbo.

The ways to fix this are not easy, but if they don't happen it will just keep getting worse. Multifamily zoning laws need to be implemented. Permitting of new construction needs to be easier and much harder for residents to block. Tax incentives need to be granted for builders of less expensive, and more modest homes and multifamily buildings. Limits need to be placed on businesses and individuals who own multiple properties. Restrictions need to be placed on short term rentals (like only being able to rent them out for 3 months a year, and only if you live in the house for at least 7 months of that year).

Supply of affordable housing isn't going to happen naturally.

Would they be able to afford it if it was a $6-700K new construction?

Its intentional.
I'd like to point out that Vancouver is in Canada's Southwest.

Yeha way to go team. Then complain that your kids have to buy places hours away and you never see your grandkids.   
Such a stupid situation to be in…
Me growing up in Santa Cruz Cali. I could never live in my hometown now.
Same story in central NJ

we are apparently to stupid to solve 4 walls and a roof, i swear money and greed is going make this species go extinct because solving whatever existential crisis that's gonna pop up will be deemed to expensive, even tho money is not used as a actual resource in the making of anything

I think people are starting to realize that homeownership isn’t the investment it once was. It’s a liability. It’s only an investment if you get passive income from it. Otherwise it’s a money pit. You never really own your home. You’re just paying the government to live in it, as long as you keep it.

posts.title: A deadly E. coli outbreak hit 15 states, but the FDA chose not to publicize it | NBC News
top_comments:
I got sick with food poisoning (salmonella) and because my state has (or at least had) a robust health department, it was traced to a particular restaurant.

Whether or not the restaurant was negligent, or just had the bad luck of having some food that was spoiled, I have no idea. But the health department folks researched it  traced it. Amazing work. This is work that takes having adequate staffing. 

I don't know if this will happen anymore in my state. But I am very appreciative of the staff at the Dept of Health who helped me and told them as much that they were rock stars.
It literally never lists the 15 states in the entire article.
Beginning to sound a lot like Fahrenheit 451, isn't it?
Yes, America is failing its citizens to allow for corporate greed
“If we stop testing right now, we’d have very few cases, if any.”

Note this discovery is in conjunction with the US FDA cuts according to reuters [https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-fda-suspends-food-safety-quality-checks-after-staff-cuts-2025-04-17/](https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-fda-suspends-food-safety-quality-checks-after-staff-cuts-2025-04-17/)

Highly concerning to US food safety, and wont make it easier for the US to export their agricultural products overseas.
Edit: this occured last year supposedly and was never reported, things are likely far worse now
TLDR: the states (cases per state) are AR (2), CO (1), IL (7), IN (8),KS (1), KY (1), MO (50), MT (1), ND (2), NE (3), OH (8), PA (1), SD (1), TN (1), WI (2)
89 cases they know about.  There are undoubtedly hundreds if not thousands of cases not reported.  I’ve been poisoned multiple times, and never once reach the level of statistic.

**Censorship by omission**
